unnormalised: Subject: Surviving the Indian Office Calendar: A Hilarious Guide to Preponing, Postponing, and Perpetual Confusion
normalised: Let's be real. Navigating the Indian office calendar is less about productivity and more about sheer survival. It's a battlefield where deadlines shift faster than the monsoon winds and meetings get "preponed" with the frequency of chai breaks. And let’s not even talk about the scheduling software – usually something from the late nineties that only understands dates in the D-D slash M-M slash Y-Y-Y-Y format, causing international colleagues to stare blankly at their screens.

unnormalised: Fellow sufferers of the corporate jungle,
normalised: It all starts innocently enough. A meeting is set for, say, sixteenth May two thousand and twenty four at two thirty P-M I-S-T. You mentally prepare, maybe even remember to charge your laptop. But then B-A-M! An email arrives: "Requesting you to prepone meeting to fifteenth May two thousand and twenty four at eleven A-M due to unavoidable circumstances." Unavoidable circumstances, of course, translating to "Boss suddenly remembered he needed to attend a wedding in Goa."

unnormalised: Let's be real. Navigating the Indian office calendar is less about productivity and more about sheer survival. normalised: And it never stops at just preponing, does it? Oh no. It’s a delicate dance of moving things forward, pushing things back, and generally losing track of what day it actually is. Just last week, I had a meeting scheduled for "next Thursday." Which Thursday, you ask? Your guess is as good as mine. I finally figured out it was twenty fifth July two thousand and twenty four only after interrogating my colleague over several cups of chai.

unnormalised: It all starts innocently enough. A meeting is set for, say, 16/05/2024 at 2:30 PM IST. You mentally prepare, maybe even remember to charge your laptop. But then BAM! An email arrives: "Requesting you to prepone meeting to 15/05/24 @ 11AM due to unavoidable circumstances." Unavoidable circumstances, of course, translating to "Boss suddenly remembered he needed to attend a wedding in Goa."
normalised: Then there's the "urgent" request to complete something by "E-O-D." Now, "E-O-D" could mean anything from five P-M to "whenever the boss feels like leaving," which, in my experience, is usually around eight P-M. And don’t even think about clarifying. Asking about the exact time of "E-O-D" is a rookie mistake that marks you as someone who doesn’t understand the true meaning of corporate commitment (read: endless working hours).

normalised: Let’s not forget the calendar invites themselves. Some people use Google Calendar, others Outlook, a few still cling to paper diaries with dates like 'August fifteenth' scribbled on them. The integration is seamless, of course... NOT! You end up with multiple entries for the same meeting, each with a slightly different time and location, leading to mass confusion and the inevitable "Sorry, I was in another meeting" excuse.

unnormalised: Then there's the "urgent" request to complete something by "EOD." Now, "EOD" could mean anything from 5:00 PM to "whenever the boss feels like leaving," which, in my experience, is usually around 8:00 PM. And don’t even THINK about clarifying. Asking about the exact time of "EOD" is a rookie mistake that marks you as someone who doesn’t understand the true meaning of corporate commitment (read: endless working hours).
normalised: The highlight of my week? When a colleague scheduled a team-building exercise for "second October," conveniently forgetting that it's Gandhi Jayanti, a national holiday. The look on his face when H-R gently reminded him was priceless. We ended up having the team-building on 'October third' instead, which, honestly, felt a bit less… celebratory.

Trying to decipher them all while juggling deadlines and dealing with a perpetually slow internet connection is a skill I believe should be added to the national curriculum. Maybe a certification in “Office Jargon Decryption”? I'd enroll!

We manage to get things done, deadlines are (mostly) met, and the meetings, however frequently they shift, eventually happen. It’s a testament to our resilience, our ability to roll with the punches, and our unwavering love for chai breaks.
